Conic Sections

So far we have analyzed points and lines. Points are expressed by ordered pairs of numbers, either in the rectangular system or the polar system. Lines are expressed in several ways; we have seen them using linear equations of \(x\) and \(y\) in various special forms, using certain polar equations, using certain parametric equations, and using certain vector equations.

The simplest equations, those with only a first-power exponent on the variable, are said to be linear. The general linear equation in \(x\) and \(y\), \(Ax+By+C=0,\), is something we already know how to handle. The graph of this is just a line. That was easy! So we already know everything about the general linear equation.

The next most simple type of equation would be the quadratic equation, where the variables are at most second power. The quadratic general form is \(Ax^2+Bxy+Cy^2+Dx+Ey+F=0\); it takes quite a bit of work to describe all the shapes that can be expressed in this form. We will introduce four of those shapes over the next three classes, and then we'll start to build up to where we can handle the general form equation. The four new shapes we will consider are circles, ellipses, parabolas, and hyperbolas.

Circles

Circles are the third fundamental shape of plane geometry, together with points and lines. Geometrically, a circle is defined as the set of points at a fixed distance \(r\), called the radius, from a fixed point \(C\), called the center.

People often mean different things by the word circle. Most often in everyday life, a circle includes not just the edge of points at that fixed distance, also called the circumference, but also the points within the circumference. From a precise mathematical point of view, we only consider the points of the circumference as being the points of the circle. The circumference divides the points of the plane into the circle itself (circumference), the points inside the circle (the interior of the circle), and the points outside the circle (the exterior). Also, we often use the term circumference to mean both the points of a circle and the length of that shape, which is \(2\pi\) times the radius.

There are other parts we should also consider from Euclidean geometry:

  • We often use the term radius for both the distance from the center to the edge of the circle and for any line segment with one end on the circumference and other end at the center.
  • Similarly, diameter could be used to refer to a line segment through the center with both ends on the circumference, or the length of any such line segment. This length is twice the radius. The number \(\pi\) is defined as the ratio of the circumference to the diameter, and it is the same in all circles no matter their size.
  • A chord is any line segment on the interior of a circle with endpoints on the circumference.
  • A secant line is any line that passes through a circle in two points, while a tangent line is a line that intersects a circle in exactly one point. Moreover, any tangent line will be perpendicular to the radius through the same point on the circumference.

Now let's think about a circle analytically. The distance formula is our key tool here. To make things easier on ourselves, let's first consider only circles whose center is at the origin \((0,0)\). Let's fix the radius as \(r\). Then according to the definition of circle, any point \((x,y)\) on the circle is at a distance \(r\) from the center \((0,0)\). Using the distance formula, we can express this as \(\sqrt{(x-0)^2+(y-0)^2}=r\). This simplifies to \(\sqrt{x^2+y^2}=r\). Squaring both sides, we get \(x^2+y^2=r^2\). In this case, squaring does not introduce any extraneous solutions, and so we get the standard form for the equation of a circle centered at the origin.

Standard Form Equation for a Circle Centered at the Origin

The standard form equation for a circle of radius \(r\) centered at the origin is \[x^2+y^2=r^2.\]

Recall that the unit circle is just the circle with equation \(x^2+y^2=1\).
